1. Introduction

In recent years, there has been significant growth in the application of machine-learning (ML) methods to weather and climate problems. Many researchers have successfully developed data-driven emulators to provide low-cost representations of the complex dynamics of the climate system. These emulators have been shown to perform as well as or better than state-of-the-art numerical weather models on short-time scales. However, the related problem of long-term atmosphere emulation, spanning ten to hundreds of years, has also emerged in the literature.

Recent studies have shown some success in ocean emulation, including an idealized model for multi-decadal timescales, a regional emulation on subseasonal timescales, and a 3D global emulation on 30-day timescales. Emulating ocean dynamics poses different challenges than emulating the atmosphere. As the risks of a changing climate continue to grow, developing reliable models to simulate the global climate will be essential for adaptation and mitigation.

This work highlights key considerations for building emulators of regional and global ocean climate models by assessing the role of boundary conditions and designing a framework for multi-scale emulation. Understanding the appropriate boundary inputs and scales for modeling velocity and temperature is critical for successfully emulating complex multi-scale ocean physics.

2. Methods

We use data from the last 20 years of a pre-industrial control simulation of the GFDL CM2.6 coupled climate model, with a nominal ocean resolution of 1/10°. We focus on emulating four regions: the Gulf Stream, the Tropics, the South Pacific, and the African Cape. The data are regridded from the native ocean resolution of 1/10° to a grid with a resolution of 1/4°. To remove mesoscale turbulence, the data is filtered at a fixed factor corresponding to 1°. For the atmospheric data, which is natively on a 1/2°-resolution grid, we use bilinear interpolation onto the 1/4°-resolution grid.

We consider the state vector predicted by the network to be Φ = (u, v, T), representing the zonal velocity, meridional velocity, and temperature, respectively, in the surface layer. We let τ = (τu, τv, Tatm) represent the state vector for the surface atmosphere boundary conditions, which are zonal wind stress, meridional wind stress, and air temperature, respectively.

2.2 Input Features

Our network is a U-Net with four upsampling and downsampling layers, yielding O(10^7) parameters. It takes in an input vector with 9 channels: three channels correspond to the ocean state Φ = (u, v, T), three channels for the atmospheric boundary τ, and three channels for the atmospheric state.
